review.title: Inferring Graphs from Cascades: A Sparse Recovery Framework
review.abstract: In the Network Inference problem, one seeks to recover the edges of an unknown graph from the observations of cascades propagating over this graph. In this paper, we approach this problem from the sparse recovery perspective. We introduce a general model of cascades, including the voter model and the independent cascade model, for which we provide the first algorithm which recovers the graph's edges with high probability and $O(s\log m)$ measurements where $s$ is the maximum degree of the graph and $m$ is the number of nodes. Furthermore, we show that our algorithm also recovers the edge weights (the parameters of the diffusion process) and is robust in the context of approximate sparsity. Finally we prove an almost matching lower bound of $\Omega(s\log\frac{m}{s})$ and validate our approach empirically on synthetic graphs.
histories: Full version of the ICML paper with the same title
review.COMMENTS: Full version of the ICML paper with the same title

metadata.title: Inferring Graphs from Cascades: A Sparse Recovery Framework

sections.heading: 2.1. Generalized Linear Cascade Models
sections.text: Let us take inspiration from generalized linear models to introduce generalized linear cascades: Definition 1. Let Xt be the indicator variable for "contagious nodes" in step t. A generalized linear cascade model is a cascade model, so that for each susceptible node j in state s in step t the probability that j in step t + 1 becomes "contagious" to Xt is a Bernoulli variable of the parameter f (θj · Xt): P (Xt + 1j = 1 | X t) = f (θj · Xt) (1), where f: R → [0, 1] in other words, each generalized linear cascade can not be encapsulated with a series of measurements (Xt, Xt + 1j).

sections.heading: 2.2. Examples
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. INDEPENDENT CASCADE MODEL
sections.text: In the independent cascade model, the nodes can be either susceptible, contagious, or immune. At t = 0, all source nodes are "contagious" and all remaining nodes are "contagious." At each step t, for each edge (i, j) where j is contagious and i is contagious, I try to infect j with probability pi, j − [0, 1]; the infection attempts are mutually independent. If successful, j becomes contagious at step t + 1. Regardless of the success i, the node i is immune at the time t + 1, so that the nodes remain contagious for only a single step. The cascade process ends when there are no contagious nodes left. If we specify the indicator of Xt as an indicator for the set of contagious nodes, the model is Line.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. THE LINEAR VOTER MODEL
sections.text: In the linear choice model, nodes can be either red or blue. Without loss of universality, we can assume that the blue nodes are contagious. The parameters of the graph are normalized in such a way that the number of nodes in each round, each node j independently selects one of its neighbors with the probability that it infects them, and assumes its color. Cascades end at a fixed horizon at the time T or when all nodes have the same color. If we use Xt to denote the indicator variable of the set of blue nodes in time step t, we have: P [Xt + 1j = 1 | X t] = m ∑ i = 1 сi, jX t = сj · Xt (V) Thus, the linear choice model is a generalized linear cascade model with inverse linking function f: z 7 → e.g.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. DISCRETIZATION OF CONTINUOUS MODEL
sections.text: Another motivation for the generalized linear cascade model is that it captures the time-discretized formulation of the well-studied continuously time-independent cascade model with exponential transmission function (CICE) of (Gomez Rodriguez et al., 2010; Abrahao et al., 2013; Daneshmand et al., 2014). Suppose that the time resolution of the discretization ε is, i.e. all nodes whose (continuous) infection time is within the interval [kε, (k + 1) ε are considered to be infected in (discrete) time step k. Suppose that Xk is the indicator vector for the amount of nodes that are "infected" before or during the short time interval. Note that unlike the discrete time-independent cascade model Xkj = 1 = ⇒ Xk + 1j = 1, i.e., there is no immune state and nodes remain contagious for the future.

sections.heading: 2.2.4. LOGISTIC CASCADES
sections.text: "Logistic cascades" is the specific case in which the function of inverse linkage is given by the logistic function f (z) = 1 / (1 + e − z + t). Intuitively, this grasps the idea that there is a threshold t, so that if the sum of the parameters of the infected parents of a node is greater than the threshold, the probability of becoming infected is close to one. This is a gentle approximation to the rule of the hard threshold of the linear threshold model (Kempe et al., 2003). As we will see later in the analysis, the problem of graph inference in logistic cascades becomes a linear inverse problem.

sections.heading: 2.3. Maximum Likelihood Estimation
sections.text: Deriving from the observed cascades of influences is the central question of the current work.

sections.heading: 3. Results
sections.text: In this section, we will apply the sparse recovery framework to analyze the assumptions under which our program (2) restores the true parameter θi of the cascade model. Furthermore, it is then possible to restore the support of θi by simple thresholds, which is a solution to the standard network inference problem. We will first provide results in the precisely sparse environment in which θi has support of the exact size. We will then loosen this sparsity constraint and provide results in the stable recovery environment in which θi is approximately s-sparing. As mentioned in Section 2.3, the maximum probability estimation program is degradable. We will henceforth focus on a single node i-V and omit the subscript i in the notations if there is no ambiguity. The recovery problem now is to evaluate a single vector from a series of observations.

sections.heading: 3.2. Approximate Sparsity
sections.text: In practice, the exact spareness is rarely verified. In particular, for social networks, it is more realistic to assume that each node has few "strong" parents and many "weak" parents. In other words, even if the boundaries determined in Section 3.1 are not exactly s-sparse, they can be approached well by s-sparse vectors. Instead of achieving an impossibility result, we show that the boundaries obtained in Section 3.1 worsen gracefully in this context. Formally, these costs are simply the "tail" of the x-sparse vectors: the sum of the m-s-smallest coordinates of ms-1 is the best s approximation to it. Then, we pay costs that are proportional to the costs raised in Section 3.1.

sections.heading: 4. A Lower Bound
sections.text: In (Netrapalli & Sanghavi, 2012), the authors set a lower limit for the number of cascades necessary to achieve a good support recovery with a constant probability under a correlation decay assumption. In this section, we consider the stable, sparse recovery setting of Section 3.2. Our goal is to obtain an information-theoretical lower limit for the number of measurements necessary to approximately restore the parameter of a cascade model from observed cascades. In (Price & Woodruff, 2011; 2012; Ba et al., 2011), similar lower limits for sparse linear inverse problems were reached. Theorem 3. Let's consider a cascade model of form (1) and a recovery algorithm A that takes random cascade measurements and outputs as input, increasing the probability that the number of cascades (over the measurements) will increase.

sections.heading: 5. Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we empirically validate the results and assumptions of Section 3 for different levels of economy and different initializations of parameters (n, m, λ, pinit), where it is the initial probability of a node being a source node. We compare our algorithms with two different state-of-the-art algorithms: GREEDY and MLE (Netrapalli & Sanghavi, 2012). As an additional benchmark, we also consider new LASSO algorithms that approach our SPARSE MLE algorithms. We evaluate the performance of the algorithms on synthetic graphs selected for their similarity to real social networks. Therefore, we consider a Watts-Strogatz graph (300 knots, 4500 edges) (Watts & Strogatz, 1998), a Barabasi-Albert graph (300 knots, 16200 edges).

sections.heading: 6. Future Work
sections.text: Solving the graph inference problem with sparse restoration techniques opens up new possibilities for future work. Firstly, the sparse recovery literature has already examined regulatory patterns that go beyond the '1 norm, in particular the swelling and adaptive lasso (van de Geer et al., 2011; Zou, 2006) Another goal would be to obtain confidence intervals for our estimator, similar to what was achieved for the lasso in the most recent series of papers (Javanmard & Montanari, 2014; Zhang & Zhang, 2014). Finally, the linear threshold model is a generally studied diffusion process and can also be considered as a generalized linear cascade with reverse linking function z 7 → 1z > 0: Xt + 1j = characters (θj · Xt − tj). This model therefore falls into the 1-bit compressed threshold model and is a generally subsuffusion frame (Bouunfouk, 2008).

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: We thank Yaron Singer, David Parkes, Jelani Nelson, Edoardo Airoldi and Or Sheffet for the helpful conversations and the anonymous reviewers for their insightful feedback and suggestions.

sections.heading: 7. Appendix
sections.text: In this appendix, we provide the missing evidence from Section 3 and Section 4. In addition, we show additional experiments during the run-time of our recovery algorithm that could not fit into the main part of the work.

sections.heading: 7.3. Running Time Analysis
sections.text: In Figure 3, we compared our algorithm with the benchmark algorithms to increase the number of nodes. In Figure 4, we compared our algorithm with the benchmarks for a fixed graph, but for the increasing number of observed cascades. In both figures, unsurprisingly, the simple greedy algorithm is the fastest. Although both the MLE algorithm and the algorithm we introduced are based on convex optimization, the MLE algorithm is faster, due to the overhead caused by the "1 regulation in (2). Runtime dependence on the number of cascades is expected to increase linearly, and the slope is greatest for our algorithm, which in turn is caused by the overhead caused by the" 1 regulation.

referenceMentions.context: Prior work has shown that the required number of observed cascades is O(poly(s) logm) (Netrapalli & Sanghavi, 2012; Abrahao et al., 2013).
Related Work The study of edge prediction in graphs has been an active field of research for over a decade (Liben-Nowell & Kleinberg, 2008; Leskovec et al., 2007; Adar & Adamic, 2005).
The algorithm was improved in later work (Gomez-Rodriguez et al., 2011), but is not known to have any theoretical guarantees beside empirical validation on synthetic networks.
The work of (Abrahao et al., 2013) studies the same continuous-model framework as (Gomez Rodriguez et al.
(Du et al., 2013) propose a similar algorithm to ours for recovering the weights of the graph under a continuous-time independent cascade model, without proving theoretical guarantees.

(Gomez Rodriguez et al., 2010) introduced the NETINF algorithm, which approximates the likelihood of cascades represented as a continuous process. The algorithm was improved in later work (Gomez-Rodriguez et al., 2011), but is not known to have any theoretical guarantees beside empirical validation on synthetic networks. Netrapalli & Sanghavi (2012) studied the discrete-time version of the independent cascade model and obtained the first O(s logm) recovery guarantee on general networks.
The work of (Du et al., 2014) is slightly orthogonal to ours since they suggest learning the influence function, rather than the parameters of the network directly.
, 2014) and (Abrahao et al., 2013) as well as the “uniformly chosen source set” assumption made in (Netrapalli & Sanghavi, 2012) verify condition 3.
In the context of Network Inference, (Netrapalli & Sanghavi, 2012) focus on the well-known discrete-time independent cascade model recalled below, which (Abrahao et al., 2013) and (Daneshmand et al.

Another motivation for the Generalized Linear Cascade model is that it captures the time-discretized formulation of the well-studied continuous-time independent cascade model with exponential transmission function (CICE) of (Gomez Rodriguez et al., 2010; Abrahao et al., 2013; Daneshmand et al., 2014).
This is a smooth approximation of the hard threshold rule of the Linear Threshold Model (Kempe et al., 2003).
Theorem 1 is a consequence of Theorem 1 in (Negahban et al., 2012) which gives a bound on the convergence rate of regularized estimators.
These results are formalized in the following theorem, which is also a consequence of Theorem 1 in (Negahban et al., 2012).
Several recent papers show that large classes of correlated designs obey the restricted eigenvalue property with high probability (Raskutti et al., 2010; Rudelson & Zhou, 2013).
Similar lower bounds were obtained for sparse linear inverse problems in (Price & Woodruff, 2011; 2012; Ba et al., 2011).

We therefore consider a WattsStrogatz graph (300 nodes, 4500 edges) (Watts & Strogatz, 1998), a Barabasi-Albert graph (300 nodes, 16200 edges) (Albert & Barabási, 2001), a Holme-Kim power law graph (200 nodes, 9772 edges) (Holme & Kim, 2002), and the recently introduced Kronecker graph (256 nodes, 10000 edges) (Leskovec et al., 2010).
We did not benchmark against other known algorithms (NETRATE (Gomez-Rodriguez et al., 2011) and FIRST EDGE (Abrahao et al.
, 2011) and FIRST EDGE (Abrahao et al., 2013)) due to the discrete-time assumption.
Several recent papers study the theoretical guarantees obtained for 1-bit compressed sensing with specific measurements (Gupta et al., 2010; Plan & Vershynin, 2014).

metadata.abstractText: In the Network Inference problem, one seeks to recover the edges of an unknown graph from the observations of cascades propagating over this graph. In this paper, we approach this problem from the sparse recovery perspective. We introduce a general model of cascades, including the voter model and the independent cascade model, for which we provide the first algorithm which recovers the graph’s edges with high probability and O(s logm) measurements where s is the maximum degree of the graph and m is the number of nodes. Furthermore, we show that our algorithm also recovers the edge weights (the parameters of the diffusion process) and is robust in the context of approximate sparsity. Finally we prove an almost matching lower bound of Ω(s log ms ) and validate our approach empirically on synthetic graphs.
